#T_SP=webanno.custom.Ecosystem|

#T_SP=webanno.custom.Locationofstudy|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Mainhypothesisandcorrespondingresults|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Method|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Reccomendationsandsuggestions|

#Text=Standards_based evaluation inform ecological restoration outcomes for a major mining activity in a global biodiversity hotspot\rTristan Campbell,�Kingsley W Dixon,�Sidney D Bradshaw,�George D.

#Text=Gann,�William Hartley,�Hans Lambers,�Grant Wardell_Johnson\rFirst published: 24 September 2024\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14236\rAuthor contributions: TC, KWD, WH conceived and designed the research; TC, WH analyzed data; TC, KWD, WH wrote the original draft; SDB, TC, KWD, GDG, WH, HL, GW_J reviewed and edited draft.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: Valter Amaral\rSECTIONS\rPDF\rTOOLS\r�\rSHARE.
#Text=Abstract.

#Text=The International Principles and Standards for the Ecological Restoration and Recovery of Mine Sites were used to assess the restoration quality of one of the world s largest mines, located in the world s most biodiverse temperate forest.

#Text=Quantitative analysis of longitudinal data spanning 35 years scored restoration quality at 2_stars against a 5_star forest ecosystem restoration target, with little indication of improvements from adaptive management.
#Text=Two_thirds of indicator plants were significantly under_represented in early_stage restoration and declined with age.
#Text=Most plant species were effectively absent, including key structural species.
#Text=Invasive plants and native legumes were persistently overabundant.

#Text=Time required for the maturation of tree species will prevent the production of fundamental ecosystem features for well over a century (  eg hollows and fallen logs), inhibiting functional fauna return (reptiles, bats, and conservation priority cockatoos in particular).

#Text=The significantly different outcome compared with previous assessments is due to the age of restoration assessed and previous assumptions that early_stage success indicate that restoration is on the correct, prolonged trajectory toward full ecological restoration.
#Text=However, previous assessment methods did not consider many key metrics of the standards, nor accurately predict future restoration trajectory.
#Text=In particluar, initial plant species richness (the only measure of biodiversity in the company s restoration completion criteria) did not reflect future restoration quality.

#Text=These substandard restoration outcomes may result from removing the deep, multi_layered bauxitic substrate�on which the ecosystem evolved and establishing restoration on shallow topsoil over a more homogenized, impervious substrate.
#Text=This study demonstrates the value of a robust, adaptable multi_factor framework and methodology to evaluate restoration outcomes.

#Text=Implications for Practice\r* Effective mine_site restoration requires standards_based�multi_factor ecosystem planning and fit_for_purpose assessment of appropriate design and duration to capture restoration trajectory.\r* Biodiverse ecosystems lacking functional colonization and succession processes require comprehensive species establishment at the commencement of restoration.\r* Restoring biodiverse old_growth ecosystems is region_, site_, and biome_specific, and success cannot be assumed.
#Text=Introduction.
#Text=Mining provides important benefits to humankind, with raw minerals and metals worth over US$2 trillion extracted annually.

#Text=Rapid growth in recent decades has created a global mining footprint of over 120,000 km2�(Maus et al�2022) and mining activity is anticipated to increase by 60% from 2020 levels by 2060 with new and increasing environmental impacts (United Nations Environment Programme�2024).
#Text=Half of the world s mines are undocumented (Maus et al�2022; Maus & Werner�2024), there are millions of non_rehabilitated legacy mines.

#Text=Where planned for, post_mining ecological restoration programs aim to reinstate biodiversity and other components of ecosystem integrity, but often fail to achieve full recovery, even with substantial scientific and resource investments (Atkinson et al�2022, Doley & Audet�2016) and are therefore more accurately defined as rehabilitation (Cross et al�2018).
#Text=Some global mining companies are revising net_gain biodiversity goals in favor of   minimizing, mitigating or remediating effects� of mining (  eg Rio Tinto�2017).

#Text=Manero et al (2021) found that loose regulatory systems resulted in companies effectively self_regulating mine closure, including in developed countries such as Australia, and there is a significant capacity gap for restoration of biodiversity post_mining, particularly in native ecosystems (  eg Gould�2011).

#Text=As a result, projects commonly aim for remediation or rehabilitation of mine sites rather than ecological restoration, leading to concerns about permanent environmental and social deficits from mining (Essah & Andrews�2016; Lamb et al�2015; Tiemann et al�2019).

#Text=The International Principles and Standards for the Ecological Restoration and Recovery of Mine Sites (Young et al�2022) (  the standards�) were developed to directly address the growing restoration capacity gap.

#Text=The standards are designed to be accessible and globally applicable, providing robust tools and approaches to guide mining projects through the restoration process, from planning to relinquishment.
#Text=They build on the widely cited global restoration standards of the Society for Ecological Restoration (Gann et al�2019), which contribute to UN restoration guidance (FAO et al�2021).
#Text=Restoration quality is assessed using key attributes that measure progress against five_star outcomes, with results visually summarized in the Ecological Recovery and Social Benefits Wheels.

#Text=Unlike the general standards for ecological restoration (Gann et al�2019), the mining standards specifically incorporate impacts from mining that are rare in general restoration projects, such as hostile substrates (  eg tailings, rock dumps, and toxic materials) and altered landforms.

#Text=The standards are also designed to be adapted to site_specific considerations and facilitate independent assessment (Dixon & Campbell�2023):   As it is a generic framework for restoration of mined sites, users must develop indicators and monitoring metrics specific to the ecosystem and their key attributes.� (Young et al�2022, p 28).

#Text=Attributes of the Ecological Recovery Wheel (ERW) are readily adapted to individual sites, biomes, and regions as has been demonstrated for the general restoration standards (Gann et al�2019), such as customisation of the ERW for restoring coastal wetlands for example�(Cadier et al�2020).

#Text=In this review, we assessed the effectiveness and adaptability of the standards by applying the ERW to Alcoa of Australia Ltd. s (Alcoa s) operations in the Southwest Australia biodiversity hotspot, where they operate one of the world s largest mines (>280 km2�to date) and clear up to 8 km2�of biodiverse temperate forest annually (Western Australian Government�2023).
#Text=The spatial scale, ecological diversity, and over 60 years of operations present a complex project that enables robust testing of the standards  applicability.
#Text=From published research and Alcoa s stated goal of   restoring healthy, resilient forest ecosystems,� (Milne�2023), we hypothesized that this standards_based approach would show:\ra.
#Text=Mined areas were restored to a state similar to the native reference ecosystem.\rb.
#Text=Quality and condition of restoration are improving with longer timeframes.\rc.
#Text=Sustained improvements through adaptive management.
#Text=Case Study Background.
#Text=Site Description.

#Text=The Northern Jarrah Forest region (NJF) in southwest Australia is the product of a long period of geological, climatic, and ecological stability, resulting in nutrient_deficient soils that drive high levels of species diversity and endemism (Hopper & Gioia�2004).
#Text=The NJF hosts over 4000 plant species and is the largest temperate forest ecosystem on a bauxite regolith (Dell & Havel�1989).

#Text=The region has 19 distinct vegetation complexes that are defined by landform position, substrate composition, and hydrology in addition to species composition (Havel�1975; Havel & Mattiske�2000).
#Text=Understory plant species composition also varies with forest history (  eg logging and fire; Wardell_Johnston & Calver�2004).

#Text=As much of the NJF has been logged in the last 150 years, large tracts of the forest are defined as   mature forest� (Bradshaw�2015) rather than   old_growth forest.� However, old growth elements are retained within logging blocks, such as large canopy trees selected for their current and future potential to provide critical habitat features (Whitford & Williams�2001; McCaw�2011), high levels of coarse woody debris (CWD; Whitford & McCaw�2019), and centuries_old understory plants ranging from clonal graminoid forms to balga (Xanthorrhoea preissii, a key tree_like monocot) and djiri (Macrozamia riedlei, the only cycad in the NJF), which can grow to heights of several meters, providing faunal habitat and mid_story structural features within the logged landscape (Fig�1; Supplement�S1).
#Text=Figure 1\rExample of the Northern Jarrah Forest on a high_quality bauxite deposit.

#Text=Note the complex, multi_layered canopy and the grasstrees (balga,�Xanthorrhoea preissii) in the foreground on the left, which are over a centuary old and are a key part of the old_growth mid_story strata which defines the ecosystem.
#Text=Mining and Restoration History\rStrip_mining for bauxite commenced in 1963, with plans to clear 10 ha annually for the production of 540,000 t of ore (Court�1961).
#Text=Progressive rehabilitation commenced in 1966 (Grant & Koch�2007), focusing on commercial (non_native) timber crops (Agnew & White�1974).
#Text=By the 1970s, 100 ha were cleared annually, but it was expected that this would never exceed 400 ha (Stewart et al�1972).

#Text=Research into reestablishing a native understory was underway in the mid_1970s and by the late 1980s, restoration aimed to reinstate a self_sustaining jarrah forest ecosystem, similar to the original forest (Nichols et al�1991).

#Text=This is reflected in evolving company_led completion criteria over time (Grant & Koch�2007; Manero et al�2021) and supported by extensive research programs, including establishing and operating an in_house production nursery, including a seed bank and tissue culture facilities, for several decades (Willyams�2021).
#Text=Six hundred to 1200 ha were cleared annually from 2010 to 2020, extracting up to 37 million tons of bauxite per year (Alcoa of Australia Ltd.�2019b), while annual rehabilitation was 320�800 ha.
#Text=By the end of 2020, approximately 280 km2�of forest ecosystem had been cleared, and restoration commenced on 215 km2.
#Text=Restoration had yet to commence on approximately 65 km2, with over a third of this gap accruing since 2010 (Fig�S1).
#Text=In late 2023, a further 35 km2�was approved for clearing, with 150 km2�under consideration for clearing within 14 years (Western Australian Government�2023).

#Text=Alcoa s current restoration approach is informed by the�International Principles and Standards for the Practice of Ecological Restoration�(Gann et al�2019) and is designed to be a   balance of reintroducing vegetation with the intent of approximating the surrounding forest richness, and ensuring sufficient functional groups are present as the ecosystems progress along a restoration trajectory toward unmined forest.� (Alcoa of Australia Ltd.�2023b).
#Text=This represents a 4_star restoration goal in the medium term, with a trajectory toward 5_star restoration in the longer term.
#Text=Methods.
#Text=Application of the Standards.

#Text=As this case study review is the first in_depth quantitative use of the standards for a major mine site, and given the complexities of the operation (threatened biodiversity hotspot, large area, complex ecosystem, and long timeframes), the first stage was a conceptual suitability assessment of the standards  ERW framework and star_rating definitions for the project.
#Text=The structure, function, and interactions of the attributes and sub_attributes were evaluated, followed by the relevance of the generic sub_attribute definitions to the project.
#Text=The current version of the ERW framework and star_rating definitions were used for this case study (V1.0, Gann et al�2024).
#Text=Literature Review.

#Text=Information was retrieved from many different sources; peer_reviewed scientific publications and conference proceedings were reviewed, with significant data were also sourced from publicly accessible reports (see Supplement�S1�and Digital Data Repository).
#Text=The reference ecosystem model was built from a large body of forestry and conservation research in addition to restoration_focused documents, and again, data in reports added significant value.
#Text=The number of qualitative and quantitative publications for each sub_attribute was tabulated to assess the depth and breadth of information available.
#Text=This guided more intensive searches for particular sub_attribute data and targeted fieldwork.

#Text=Data Collection and Collation\rWhere sufficiently detailed data were available, they were digitized and combined within sub_attributes to build longitudinal and chronosequence datasets for the assessment of restoration trajectory and the impact of adaptive management over time.

#Text=Vegetation surveys were conducted in spring 2023 to provide additional data on restoration, in particular (a) increase in the timespan of longitudinal data, (b) the effect of fire histories, (c) species abundance and rates of accumulation, and (d) the growth and structure of the canopy.

#Text=Vegetation surveys were primarily conducted per Alcoa s standardized 80 m2�nested plots (  eg Standish et al�2015,�2021) in areas handed back to the government (see Section�4.4.1) and where practical coincident with previous survey locations using established survey pegs.

#Text=Data Analysis and Restoration Evaluation\rAs summarized in the data analysis flowchart (Fig�S2), the significance of differences between groups of data (  eg restoration areas versus reference model, different restoration practices, and restoration ages) was assessed with one_way tests.

#Text=With ecological studies often having low statistical power (Lemoine et al�2016), the statistical power and likelihood of Type S (sign) and Type M (magnitude) errors were also assessed where appropriate (Gelman & Carlin�2014).
#Text=A similar assessment process was followed for linear mixed models.
#Text=Where data allowed, similarity measures were compared for both presence/absence versus abundance data and pairwise versus multi_site aggregation of site data.
#Text=Period of Evaluation.
#Text=Alcoa s restoration from 1988 onwards was assessed, as it has been since then that Alcoa s goal has been to restore a functional jarrah forest ecosystem (Nichols et al�1991).

#Text=While significant research investment by Alcoa has resulted in adaptive management of restoration practices over time (Koch�2015), a core component of restoration evaluation is the restoration trajectory (Grant�2006; Manero et al�2021).
#Text=Accordingly, the restoration trajectory has been primarily assessed with longitudinal data from Alcoa s older restoration areas (1988 to late 1990s).

#Text=Adaptive management effects have been assessed by comparing more recent areas of restoration with older areas at the same age of restoration (  eg comparing 8_year_old restoration established in 1999 and 2015).

#Text=As old_growth elements, which can take more than a century to form, are key features of the reference ecosystem, it is not reasonable to directly compare such features between restoration and reference sites.

#Text=Therefore, these elements were assessed based on their widespread presence or absence in restoration after several decades, as well as the presence or absence of sources that may create these elements in the future, as an indication of a likely restoration trajectory (converging, diverging, or unchanging).

#Text=For old_growth species in the reference ecosystem, such as the native cycad (Macrozamia riedlei), grass trees (Xanthorrhoea preissii), and clonal Cyperaceae and Restionaceae, their presence/absence in restoration sites determines old_growth ecosystem trajectory for these structurally important understory species.
#Text=Results.
#Text=Applicability of the Standards\rThe standards  generic framework, including attributes and sub_attributes, was applicable and relevant to the project.
#Text=The general definitions of rating levels in the standards were mostly applicable; the�Species composition�metric was adjusted to the presence and abundance of key species present.
#Text=This is covered in more detail in Section�4.3�and was a finding of a recent Alcoa_funded review (Jaspar et al�2023).
#Text=Interactions between attributes influence individual and cumulative restoration quality ratings.
#Text=Figure�2�outlines the first_order network of these interactions, with all six attributes of the standards interacting to various degrees.
#Text=For example,�Physical conditions�influence the five other attributes and have some influence from�Absence of threats, while�Ecosystem function�is influenced by all other attributes.
#Text=Therefore, while attributes have equal weighting in the ERW star_rating calculation, this interaction network results in ratings of higher_order attribute more dependent fundamental attributes.
#Text=Figure 2\rNetwork of interaction of the six ecosystem attributes of the standards.
#Text=Arrows indicate the direction of influence between attributes, with the thickness of the arrow proportional to the number of sub_attributes contributing to the influence.

#Text=Previous qualitative to semi_quantitative assessments of overall restoration quality (Koch & Hobbs�2007; Manero et al�2021,   eg) used simple metrics based on one point in time for assessment and therefore did not capture this intrinsic weighting of importance nor the trajectory of restoration.

#Text=Where frameworks for more integrated monitoring over time are presented in the literature (  eg Grant�2006), there is little evidence of such monitoring being undertaken, noting that the biodiversity monitoring reported annually to the government does not require�plant species data for restoration after 18 months age nor fauna against a benchmark.

#Text=The literature review summary (Figure�S4) found that while there was a significant volume of research regarding the vegetation and fauna species (over 40 publications for each), there were significantly fewer publications for substrate condition (with the majority of these assessing the top 10 cm or substrate�or topsoil) or quantifying threats to restoration.
#Text=Reference Ecosystem Definition\rThe reference ecosystem benchmark for assessing restoration success is fundamental to the standards.

#Text=For this review, the reference ecosystem was defined by the vegetation complexes where the majority of Alcoa s mining occurs; these reference sites lie largely within the overall envelope of the complex spatial mosaic of unmined and mined areas (see Fig�3).

#Text=As jarrah forest vegetation is highly stratified by landform position and defined by substrate as well as vegetation species (Havel�1975; Bell & Heddle�1989; Havel & Mattiske�2000), the reference ecosystem definition explicitly includes�Physical conditions�as well as�Species composition.

#Text=Figure 3\rLeft: Alcoa s mining operations in Western Australia within the context of the Northern Jarrah Forest Region, showing areas of cleared land, mining impacts, and remaining native forest.
#Text=Current expansion plans are also indicated.
#Text=Right: Detail of operational area, showing different stages of mining and restoration activities.

#Text=As bauxite ore is also stratified by landform (Agnew & White�1974), mining occurs predominantly in one vegetation complex (Dwellingup), which is defined as an open forest of�Eucalyptus marginata�(jarrah) and�Corymbia calophylla�(marri) with a second tree story of�Allocasuarina fraseriana,�Banksia grandis, and�Persoonia longifolia�and a highly diverse understory, occurring on mid_ to upland slopes (Havel & Mattiske�2000).
#Text=Soils are yellow brown sandy gravels with lateritic duricrust with good, deep profile water infiltration and storage capacity (from the thick bauxitic weathering profile).
#Text=The�Physical conditions�attribute benchmark is summarized in Figure�4.
#Text=Figure 4\rTypical pre_ and post_mining geological, geochemical and jarrah root structure profiles.
#Text=Data compiled from Anand et al (1991), Kew et al�(2007a,�2007b); Kimber (1974), Soltangheisi et al (2023), and Szota et al (2007)).

#Text=PAW is plant available water (kPa), UCS is uncompressed strength (nKm2), rippability (bar) is effort required to mechanically rip to 1.5 m depth (as per standard restoration practice to promote root growth).

#Text=From this stratification, of the 21 site_vegetation types that occur across the NJF (i.e. vegetation defined by survey plot_scale variability rather than by vegetation complexes that are defined by landform_scale features), only three are substantially impacted by mining operations (site types P, S, and T; Koch�2015).

#Text=To account for the complex, interrelated spatio_temporal effects of logging and fire history (Wardell_Johnston & Calver�2004), the reference ecosystem has been defined from reference sites with a range of logging and fire histories.
#Text=This is consistent with Alcoa s published research (  eg Standish et al�2015,�2021), unless the effects of fire were specifically studied.

#Text=For�Species composition, the�Desirable plants�benchmark was calculated from the importance of key indicator plant species for the main site_vegetation types impacted by mining (Bell & Heddle�1989), scaled by the impacted area of each vegetation community type (see Table�1).
#Text=The lack of quantitative fauna reference models (Jaspar et al�2023) means that�Desirable animals�assessment relies primarily on paired surveys between reference and restoration sites.
#Text=Table 1.

#Text=�Average rates of presence/absence and density in 80 m2�survey plots for key indicator species of vegetation types within the jarrah forest (as defined by Havel�1975; Bell & Heddle�1989) and structural species.
#Text=Key indicator species importance of 3 is moderate and 5 is critical (i.e. if this species is not present, the area would be classified as a different vegetation type).

#Text=Note that these indicator species are for mapping vegetation types within jarrah forest, and species that are widespread across the forest (i.e. are sufficiently common to not be useful for discriminating between vegetation types) are not included in the   Indicator�species importance   column.

#Text=Structural species are important to the vegetation structure, but a indicators for the vegetation types most impacted by mining as these are generally common across many vegetation types in the jarrah forest._\rSpecies\rIndicator species importance\rStructural species\rReference ecosystem presence\r18_Month restoration\r16_Year restoration\r29_Year restoration\rReference ecosystem density (stems per ha)\r29_Year restoration\rHovea chorizemifolia(L)\r5\r\r70%\r23%\r0%\r0%\r193\r0\rBanksia grandis\r4\rY\r65%\r15%\r6%\r12%\r190\r8\rLeucopogon capitellatus(R)\r4\r\r35%\r0%\r6%\r12%\r71\r27\rAcacia urophylla�(L)\r3\r\r35%\r47%\r38%\r0%\r163\r0\rA. browniana(L)\r3\r\r6%\r0%\r13%\r71%\r15\r564\rAdenanthos barbiger�(R)\r3\r\r68%\r12%\r0%\r0%\r427\r0\rAllocasurina fraseriana\r3\rY\r30%\r38%\r6%\r24%\r51\r45\rLeucopogon verticillatus(R)\r3\r\r25%\r3%\r0%\r4%\r70\r27\rPhyllanthus calycinus\r3\r\r57%\r47%\r19%\r4%\r530\r492\rStyphelia propinqua�(R) (prev.

#Text=�Leucopogon propinquus)\r3\r\r41%\r1%\r6%\r0%\r149\r0\rStyphelia tenuiflora\r3\r\r30%\r0%\r0%\r3%\r74\r42\rTrymalium ledifolium\r3\r\r43%\r48%\r94%\r4%\r595\r764\rMacrozamia riedlei�(R)\r_\rY\r65%\r3%\r0%\r10%\r160\r17\rPersoonia longifolia�(R)\r_\rY\r57%\r5%\r0%\r13%\r194\r38\rXanthorrhoea gracilis�(R)\r_\rY\r83%\r0%\r41%\r20%\r479\r95\rXanthorrhoea preissii�(R)\rS\rY\r71%\r44%\r0%\r6%\r1427\r72\rThe�Structural diversity�attribute derives trophic and spatial information from the above benchmarks.
#Text=The�All strata�sub_attribute was based on the density of plant species that comprise the structural layers of the vegetation communities.
#Text=In addition to the second_story tree species noted above, this includes the ecologically and structurally significant balga (Xanthorrhoea preissii) and djiri (Macrozamia riedlei).

#Text=Monitoring Considerations\rVegetation Plot Design and Reference Ecosystem\rNJF vegetation is typified by a number of common key indicator species, with most non_key indicator species at low densities across the vegetation type (one_third of species in the standard 80 m2�survey plots are single occurrences; Mattiske Consulting�2021).

#Text=The asymmetric abundance of species across the reference ecosystem means presence/absence_based similarity metrics are a poor representation of compositional similarity (Leinster & Cobbold�2012).
#Text=Conversely, abundance_based indices can result in high similarities when a significant number of less_dense or rare species are lacking.
#Text=Despite their low numbers, sparse or rare species often provide unique ecosystem functions and/or resilience (Walker et al�1999; Lyons et al�2005).
#Text=Pairwise average Sorensen similarities in the reference system are significantly affected by the average distance between plots (Supplement�S1) and can vary by over 60%.
#Text=Bray�Curtis similarities are likewise affected.
#Text=Furthermore, pairwise similarity measures do not account for patterns of co_occurrence of species.

#Text=The complex spatial distribution of a large number of species across the NJF means that, while the 80 m2�plots commonly used for monitoring do capture a number of species (typically 60�70 species per plot, Supplement�S1), species accumulation continues beyond this with a gradual decrease in the accumulation rate.

#Text=At 1000 m2�of combined plots, an average of six additional species are accumulated per plot, despite a species turnover of nearly 80% by this point, and at 5000 m2, an additional one species is accumulated per 80 m2plot (Supplement�S1).
#Text=Therefore, reference models for the similarity index calculations in the NJF should consider both small_ and large_scale species distributions.
#Text=Fauna Survey Data\rFauna survey data in published sources are primarily from trapped and observed specimens.
#Text=While this provides information on presence/absence of species, it does not necessarily equate to similar functional habitat utilization or occupancy (Cross et al�2020).
#Text=There appear to be limited studies quantitatively comparing functional habitat utilization between reference sites and restoration (six studies were found during the literature search).
#Text=Several publications concluding the high similarity of fauna in restoration areas to the reference model have significant underlying limitations (Supplement�S1).
#Text=These examples emphasize the need for a standards_based approach for assessing restoration outcomes.
#Text=Restoration Quality\rRating Summary\rAlcoa achieved 2 stars of a potential 5 stars for full ecosystem restoration, or 4 stars for Alcoa s medium_term restoration goal.
#Text=The underlying basis for these scores is summarized in Table�2�and Figure�5, with details in Supplement�S1.
#Text=Table 2.
#Text=�Summary of sub_attribute ratings.
#Text=See Table�S1�for detailed descriptions.
#Text=Blank boxes indicate there are only three sub_attributes for that primary attribute.

#Text=Attribute\rSub_attribute 1\rSub_attribute 2\rSub_attribute 3\rAbsence of threats\r2.3_star average\rOver_utilization (3 stars)\rHigh water use, deficiency of topsoil for existing and future restoration.
#Text=Unchanging\rInvasive species (2 stars)\rSignificantly increased weed load, permanently in the soil seed bank.
#Text=Unchanging\rContamination (2 stars)\rPer_ and polyfluoroalkyl (PFAS)�(historic but still present), regular large hydrocarbon spills.

#Text=Unchanging\rPhysical conditions\r2.0_star average\rPhysical substrate (2 stars)\rSignificantly harder profile below replaced topsoil than pre_mining with markedly different hydrological properties, loss of indurated duricrust.
#Text=Unchanging\rChemical substrate (2 stars)\rPlant growth soil nutrient concentrations and profile reduced (between 2 and 20 times less).
#Text=Unchanging\rWater chemo_physical (2 stars)\rSignificantly altered hydrological model (short term storage, filtration, and water use by vegetation).
#Text=Unchanging\rSpecies composition\r2.0_star average\rDesirable plants (2 stars)\rModerate to low initial similarity declines with time.
#Text=Many key indicators and structural species absent.
#Text=Declining\rDesirable animals (2 stars)\rModerate to low similarity for many families and transient use with limited evidence of residence.
#Text=�Unchanging\rNo undesirable species (2 stars)\rSignificant (and permanent) high weed load.
#Text=Persistent dominance of legumes and hard_seeded species.
#Text=Unchanging.
#Text=Structural diversity\r1.7_star average\rAll strata present (2 stars)\rLow understory composition, mid_story species absent, overstory not developing per reference ecosystem.
#Text=Unchanging\rAll trophic levels (2 stars)\rKey faunal trophic levels are low (predator and pollinator), low plant species richness, and similarity.
#Text=Unchanging\rSpatial mosaic (1 star)\rPlant species low and declining, does not increase over larger areas.
#Text=Uniform canopy, uncertain trajectory.
#Text=High degree of fragmentation.
#Text=Declining\rEcosystem function\r2.0_star average\rProductivity, cycling (2 stars)\rAltered substrate chemistry, low species richness, and tropic levels.
#Text=Declining\rHabitat interactions (2 stars)\rLow species composition and structural diversity.
#Text=Declining\rResilience, recruitment (2 stars)\rHigher fire severity, depleted native seed bank, lack of fire resprouting species, and depleted fungal community.

#Text=Declining\rExternal exchanges\r2.0_star average\rLandscape flows (2 stars)\rLow productivity and cycling, poor spatial mosaic, reduced streamflow, PFAS, and hydrocarbon contamination into catchments.
#Text=Unchanging\rGene flows (2 stars)\rPermanently reduced species richness, poor habitat interactions, and landscape flows.
#Text=Unchanging\rHabitat links (2 stars)\rLow species richness, spatial mosaic, and trophic levels with poor development or absence of strata.

#Text=Unchanging\r\rFigure 5\rEcological recovery wheel assessment of restoration outcomes for Alcoa mine sites post_1988 when the company formally adopted measurable goals for full reinstatement of the jarrah forest ecosystem (Koch & Hobbs�2007).

#Text=The attributes and sub_attributes of the wheel and the benchmarks for assessment are as per V1.0 of the sub_attribute table of the standards (Gann et al�2024) with minor modifications to increase relevance to the ecosystem and mining and restoration operations (  eg the biodiverse and spatially_complex�ecosystem and the large spatial extent of disturbance).

#Text=The aggregate score of 2_stars out of 5_stars across nearly 40 years of restoration indicates that the mined areas do not represent full recovery of a native ecosystem and includes the effect of changes in restoration practices over time.
#Text=This means restoration areas do not:\ra.
#Text=Return to a state similar to the native reference ecosystem,\rb.
#Text=Improve over longer timeframes, nor\rc.
#Text=Show sustained improved outcomes from adaptive management processes.

#Text=Therefore, restoration does not meet the company objective of their 4_star medium_term restoration goal, and restoration is not on a trajectory to achieve their 5_star long_term goal as defined in Section�2.

#Text=This is reflected in the lack of restoration meeting the agreed government completion criteria (Milne�2023), noting that the completion criteria are based on Alcoa s medium_term goal and the assumption that the restoration areas will become more similar to the reference ecosystem over time.

#Text=Although Certificates of Completion were issued for two areas in 2005 and 2007, this was for the express purposes of government water management trials requiring the thinning of dense trees in restoration areas.

#Text=The certificates state the areas have met criteria appropriate for the handover by the government, which   �does not necessarily equate to all of the rehabilitation completion criteria applicable to the suite of different age and types of rehabilitation present in the area at the time, having been met.
#Text=(Milne�2023).
#Text=See Figure�1�for examples of typical restoration from these areas, which include different times since fire after restoration commenced (see Section�4.4.9�for the importance of fire history).
#Text=These certificates total 1355 ha, or less than 5% of the area impacted over the past 60 years, with no certificates issued since 2007.
#Text=Comparison With Previous Assessments\rAs noted under Section�3.2, previous assessments of overall restoration quality often had simple metrics at a point in time.
#Text=For example, Koch and Hobbs (2007) rely on plant species and/or similarity to the reference ecosystem in restoration at 18 months as the defining attribute for biodiversity.

#Text=Where higher_order attributes were considered (such as structure), it was assumed that a high initial species richness would result in the development of suitable structure as restoration ages, without assessing the presence or absence of key structural species.
#Text=A comparison of these assessments for restoration aged 18 months (as per Koch & Hobbs�2007) and greater than 25 years (as per the data used in this case study) is provided.
#Text=Table�3, which gives an average score of 90% at 18 months and 50% at greater than 25 years with simplistic metrics, several of which are not relevant to biodiversity values.
#Text=This is a similar score to the 2 stars of a 5_star restoration goal in this case study (40%), showing there is consistency in outcomes over longer timeframes.
#Text=Table 3.
#Text=�Comparison of restoration at 18 months, as per Koch and Hobbs (2007) versus greater than 25 years of age.

#Text=Measure\rScore (18 months)\rNotes\rScore (>25 years)\rNotes\rLand use assessment\rWater production\r8\rPossible reduced stream yield\r4\rLong_term reduced stream yield, contamination risks\rTimber production\r10\rTree stocking and growth meet requirements\r7\rLow bole heights mean timber quality is poorer than expected at 18 months\rRecreation\r10\rMine restoration can accommodate any requirement\r7\rAged restoration judged as   poor� quality by recreational forest users\rConservation\r8\rResprouter/reseeder imbalance.

#Text=Old hollows absent for a century or more\r2\rSignificant species and structural deficits\rTotal\r36/40\r90% (unweighted)\r20/40\r50% (unweighted�note low conservation score)\rMultiple ecosystem components\rWater cycle\r9\rHigher score than that of   water production� due to less human_based requirement\r4\rLong_term reduced stream yield, contamination risks effect environment, not just human consumption\rCarbon cycle\r10\rIs on track but will take decades to reach unmined forest values\r6\rSignificant structural deficits\rLevy pole structure\r10\rControlled by correct species composition\r7\rLow bole heights mean timber quality is poorer than expected at 18 months\rMulti_layered forest\r10\rControlled by correct species composition\r4\rSignificant structural deficits from missing species\rPlant species richness\r10\rRoutinely achieved for nearly 20 years now\r4\rLess than 50% present\rPlant species similarity\r6\rUsing Sorensen similarity index\r2\rUsing Bray�Curtis similarity index\rTotal\r55/60\r92% (unweighted)\r28/60\r45% (unweighted, note levy pole structure not relevant to biodiversity)\rOne key measure\rSoil organic carbon\r10\rIs on track but will take decades to reach unmined forest values\r8\rApproaching forest values\rBiodiversity\r8\rResprouter/seeder imbalance.

#Text=Old hollows absent for century or more\r3\rSignificant species and structural deficits\rTotal\r18/20\r90% (unweighted)\r11/20\r55% (note soil carbon has little relationship to biodiversity)\rSubstrate Condition\rThe truncated and heavily altered post_mining substrate profile of the restoration areas (Fig�4) is likely to have a significant effect on restoration quality and resilience.
#Text=Topsoil in the NJF ranges from 10 to 100 cm thick (average approximately 50 cm).

#Text=Target topsoil thickness for restoration is 30 cm (Alcoa of Australia Ltd.�2023b), which is on average 40% thinner than the reference ecosystem and results in the underlying pallid clay being visible at times at the surface after ripping.

#Text=Substrate for root development is limited to the pit_floor ripping depth of 1.5 m (Szota et al�2007; Kew et al�2007), compared with an average of 12 m, and up to 40 m in the reference ecosystem (Kimber�1974; Carbon et al�1980).

#Text=In addition to the truncated profile, physical and chemical attributes of the restoration substrate are significantly different (Fig�4), with key micronutrients for plant health substantially reduced and affecting leaf chemistry (Supplement�S1).
#Text=Restoration landforming is designed to be internally draining to reduce erosion and streamflow turbidity (Alcoa of Australia Ltd.�2023b), effectively to create seasonally perched water tables.
#Text=These are rarely present in the reference ecosystem and, if present, only persist for a few days (Schofield et al�1989; Robinson�1997).

#Text=This is a significant change to the hydrology of mined areas and is more typical of valley floors in the NJF than the mid_to_up_slope areas where the highest quality bauxite and jarrah trees both occur.
#Text=Topsoil Seed Bank\rFresh, precision_stripped topsoil delivers up to three_quarters of the initial plant species richness in restoration and is a crucial resource (Koch�2015).

#Text=Species richness of applied seed does not affect the species richness of restoration (linear regression�  = 0.91, data from Standish et al�2015) and has low similarity to vegetation composition (Bray�Curtis similarity between seed mix and vegetation at 18 months is 5.6% +/_ 2.8%, data from Standish et al�2015).

#Text=Double_stripped� direct_return topsoil, where the top 5�15 cm of soil from newly cleared areas is stripped and spread directly on a new restoration site, generally results in higher species richness and similarity to the reference ecosystem than other topsoil_handling methods (Tacey & Glossop�1980; Standish et al�2015; Daws et al�2022) and has been Alcoa s preferred method since 1982 (Hunt Steering Committee�1984).
#Text=However, this occurs in less than 50% of restoration (Koch et al�1996) due to operational and soil hygiene constraints.
#Text=Between 1992 and 2010, fewer than 30% of restoration vegetation monitoring plots received double_stripped direct_return topsoil, with no improvement over that time (Supplement�S1).
#Text=Double_stripping to more than 2 cm depth dilutes the soil seed bank, resulting in different species compositions in the reference ecosystem (Tacey & Glossop�1980).

#Text=This includes an overabundance of native legumes due to 92% of the seed bank only germinating when shallower than 2 cm (Tacey & Glossop�1980), whereas many legumes can germinate from more than 10 cm (Grant et al�1996).

#Text=Stripping to 15 cm reduces germinable seed density by five to seven times, and surface ripping only increases the germinable seed density for legumes, resulting in legumes comprising twice the proportion of plants in restored areas compared with reference sites or cleared forest sites (Koch et al�1996; Supplement�S1).
#Text=Weeds are increased significantly from topsoil_handling operations, but not from forest clearing activities.

#Text=The seed profile diverges further from the reference ecosystem over time, with native legumes remaining overabundant and non_native invasive species comprising over half the topsoil seedbank after a decade, compared with 2�16% in the reference ecosystem (Ward et al�1997; Smith et al�2000).
#Text=These differences are reinforced following fire at restoration sites (Smith et al�2000; Section�4.4.9).

#Text=Desirable Plants\rAs restoration and the reference ecosystem follow the   Initial Floristics Model� of succession (Grant�2006), restoration suffers from significantly reduced species richness over time (Standish et al�2023, Fig�6).
#Text=By 25 years, restoration typically has less than half the species of the reference ecosystem, and most indicator species are less common or absent.
#Text=Figure 6\rChanges in plant species over time from in 80 m2�survey plots in restoration areas compared with the reference ecosystem.
#Text=Data are from Standish et al (2021), Norman & Koch (2005), Mattiske Consulting (2010), and field data acquired in 2023 (digital data repository).

#Text=The generic reference ecosystem has an average richness of 61 species per 80 m2�plot (Alcoa of Australia Ltd.�2019), with (A) showing that after 25 years species richness is under half of this value.

#Text=(C) and (D) are the changes in species richness and similarity to the reference ecosystem over time, both for the increasing age of restoration and for the year of restoration (i.e. allowing for improved practices through the adaptive management process).
#Text=Note issues regarding pairwise similarity calculations as discussed in the text.
#Text=While initial species richness in restoration improved from 1988 to 2003, the decline in species richness with age did not.
#Text=Restoration after 2000 routinely achieved initial species richness similar to reference sites, but not similar species composition (Standish et al�2015,�2021).
#Text=By 11�15 years of age, restoration from this period had significantly fewer species than restoration from 1988 to 1990 of similar age (  < 0.001, Fig�6).
#Text=Therefore, improvements in initial species richness are not an indicator of improved restoration outcomes over time.

#Text=Similarity declines as restoration ages (nonsignificant linear regression,�  = 0.051, Fig�6), though this becomes significant when restoration younger than 6 years is excluded (  < 0.001), as shorter_lived species that are largely absent in the reference ecosystem have senesced but not re_recruited in restoration areas.
#Text=Similarity of older restoration improved from 1988 to 2003, with 11_ to 15_year_old restoration significantly more similar after 1990 (Kruskal�Wallis�p < 0.01).

#Text=As these improved similarities are linked with reduced species richness, the improvements are due to the reduced presence of undesirable species rather than the increased presence of desirable species.

#Text=Across the vegetation communities most impacted, there are over 100 species of   recalcitrant� plants (fire_resistant resprouter species that are difficult to regenerate from seed) that provide important ecological values (Supplement S1).
#Text=This includes long_lived clonal species (Restionaceae and Cyperaceae) with graminoid_growth forms that provide important structural and functional diversity (Shane et al�2005).
#Text=Recalcitrants comprise 30% of the species in the reference model and comprise 50% of understory plants by abundance, averaging over 12,000 plants/ha (Supplement�S1).
#Text=Restoration with direct_return topsoil averages 1200 recalcitrant plants/ha at 18 months of age from the soil seed bank (Supplement�S1).

#Text=While many of the recalcitrant species occur in a spatially complex pattern across the landscape, 4 of the 12 key indicator species are recalcitrants (Table�1) and are sufficiently ubiquitous to occur across the project area.
#Text=None of these species is present in restoration at densities similar to the reference ecosystem (Table�1; Fig�6).
#Text=Undesirable Species\rStudies and reports show that non_native invasive plants (weeds) and legumes are common in restoration, but not in the reference ecosystem (Supplement�S1).

#Text=Weeds are typically nearly half of the most common species in restoration (Smith et al�2000; Grant & Norman�2006) and are dominated by dicotyledon species, where there is limited ability for selective control using herbicides.
#Text=Legumes comprise three to four times the proportion of understory in restoration compared with the reference ecosystem (Supplement S1).
#Text=Native annuals comprise 1 or 2 of the 10 most common understory species in restoration but none in the reference ecosystem (Supplement S1).
#Text=The net effect of increased abundance of undesirable species in restoration is that typically only one key indicator species is among the 10 most common species.
#Text=Ecosystem Structure\rSimilar to desirable plants, structural species are significantly less common to absent in restoration (Table�1).
#Text=Only the second_story tree (Allocasurina fraseriana) is present at similar rates.

#Text=Therefore, restoration has low structural similarity to the reference ecosystem after more than 30 years and is unlikely to improve over time as key species are absent across large areas of restoration and do not naturally migrate (Hopper et al2021).

#Text=While post_mining substrate is conducive to early growth of canopy tree species (Bleby et al�2009), there are indications that growth structure in restoration is closer to the lower rainfall zone east of Alcoa s operations (Supplement�S1), while conversely, crown architecture is indicative of non_resource constrained growth (Bleby et al�2009).
#Text=Early forking of canopy trees is significantly more common in restoration (including compared with regrowth in reference sites; Bradshaw�2015), causing reduced bole heights.

#Text=As the height of jarrah trees is typically two to three times the bole height (Bradshaw�2015), the 60% of jarrah trees in restoration with low bole heights (Koch & Ward�2005) may indicate a restricted capacity to develop the distinctive structure of mature, high_quality jarrah trees, even over long timeframes.
#Text=In the reference ecosystem, lower bole heights are more common in lower_lying areas of the landform, or in the lower rainfall zone to the east (Bradshaw�2015).
#Text=Balga and djiriji are common in the NJF, forming a unique old_growth mid_story structural layer (Fig�1) that is conspicuously absent from nearly all restoration (Fig�7, Supplement�S1).

#Text=These very slow growing, long_lived species (  stem� growth of approximately 1.4 cm per year for balga, living for over 300 years; Lamont & Downes�1979) provide faunal habitat resources (shelter and food), and djiriji fulfills a nitrogen_fixing service (Pate et al�1988).

#Text=Similarly, dryland sedges (Cyperaceae) and restiads (Restionaceae) are common and widespread rhizomatous species throughout the reference ecosystem and are largely absent in restoration (Daws & Koch�2015; Koch�2015).
#Text=Their clonal behavior means they form long_lived clumps that may be over a century old (Meney & Dixon�1995).

#Text=These recalcitrant elements are major contributors to the stability, structural and trophic diversity of the reference ecosystem, and facilitate phosphorus uptake for neighboring species (Lambers et al�2022).

#Text=While propagation methods for some of these poorly represented recalcitrant species have been developed (  eg�Persoonia�spp.; Chia et al�2016), the capacity to reinstate and ensure the longevity of species remains uncertain given the persistent decline in species richness over time in restoration.
#Text=Alcoa s restoration program includes the reinstatement of CWD, at densities less than 5% of the reference ecosystem.
#Text=Artificial CWD lasts for less than half the time required for restoration to produce hollow_bearing trees or fallen logs capable of supporting habitat (Grigg & Steele�2011).
#Text=The faunal habitat gap in restoration will increase for more than a century as restoration ages and cannot be compensated by increasing the initial density of CWD.

#Text=Desirable Animals\rReported faunal species richness in restoration initially increases over time, with the timeframe for the return of fauna groups and species dependent on the age of the restoration and ecosystem structure (Nichols & Nichols�2003).
#Text=Bird, ant, and flying insect species richness are similar to the reference ecosystem after 8 years (Nichols & Nichols�2003; Tudor et al�2023).
#Text=Monitoring programs for some restoration areas have recorded 100% of the reference ecosystem mammals and 90% of the birds within 5 years (Alcoa of Australia Ltd.�2023a).

#Text=However, as per�Desirable plants, species richness does not mean community composition is similar, that all key species are present or, in the case of fauna, utilization, or residency in restoration is similar (Cross et al�2020).

#Text=A recent review concluded that at 15 years, fauna in restoration is not on a trajectory toward the reference ecosystem (Terrestrial Ecosystems�2023), despite the species richness levels stated above, though this may be in part due to the sampling design for the reference ecosystem.

#Text=Studies that have quantitatively assessed fauna behavior between reference sites and restoration have often found altered and/or reduced activity in restoration areas (McGregor et al�2014; Doherty et al�2016; Triska et al�2016; Burgar et al�2017).

#Text=Multiple studies have concluded that the lack of habitat features and altered structure compared to the reference can act as filters for some species of fauna in restoration while encouraging higher utilization for other species, resulting in an altered community composition (  eg bats; Burgar et al�2017; reptiles; Triska et al�2016).

#Text=While most to all reptile species have been recorded in restoration younger than 15 years, composition remains dissimilar as restoration ages (Nichols & Nichols�2003; Triska et al�2016) and a number of species present initially show declining numbers.
#Text=Carnivorous reptile and bird species are less common, or absent, while omnivorous species are more common (Supplement�S1).

#Text=Likewise, while invertebrate species richness and overall functional assemblage on a family level can be similar in restoration to the reference ecosystem after a decade or less (Majer et al�2013; Tudor et al�2023).

#Text=However, when assessed as per the rating definitions of the ERW and the�data analysis�methodology of this case study for consistency of results, Sorenson similarities at a species level remain under 50% (Supplement�S1).
#Text=This is consistent with both Majer et al (2013) and Tudor (2021) noting that, despite the similarity of functional assemblages, these may not reflect the composition of pre_mining forest.

#Text=The World Conservation Union_listed critically endangered Baudin s cockatoo (Zanda baudinii) and vulnerable forest Red_tail cockatoo (Calyptorhynchus banksii naso) rely on mature canopy trees for roosting, nesting hollows, and seed forage (Cooper et al�2002).

#Text=While feeding has been recorded in restoration, there is significantly reduced forage (Doherty et al�2016; GHD�2021), which is further impacted by the increased risk of higher severity fires, which reduces seed production in canopy trees over extended periods of time (Dixon et al�2023).

#Text=With an average of nine trees of hollow_bearing age per hectare found in prospective mining areas (GHD�2021) and breeding success heavily reliant on forage availability (Mastrantonis et al�2019), reestablishing the aged forest overstory is essential for sustaining the populations of these conservation significant birds.
#Text=Ecosystem Trajectory and Resilience\rRestoration areas are not on the expected trajectory based on plant species richness and similarity at 18 months (Table�3; Fig�8).

#Text=The state and succession restoration model developed by Grant (2006) and further refined by Alcoa (Manero et al�2021) excludes several key aspects of restoration (such as species similarity, ecosystem structure, and function), potentially indicating limited consideration and therefore management and rectification options for these deficits.
#Text=Figure 7\rExamples of typical restoration from the spring 2023 surveys.
#Text=Note that these are all areas of post_1988 restoration handed back to the government betweeen 2005 and 2007.
#Text=Figure 8\rRestoration trajectory model adapted from Grant (2006), which defines restoration quality by legume and canopy tree density and understory richness.
#Text=S� boxes are desired restoration states;   D� boxes are states deviated from the desired restoration trajectory; and   M� boxes are management controls to correct deviated states.
#Text=Management for three of the nine identified undesirable states assumes the state will improve with more time, contrary to the findings of this case study.

#Text=The red arrows show the general trajectory of restoration found in this case study according to the defined framework, with the red text boxes describing key aspects and the relevant model states and management options also highlighted in red.
#Text=Note that the restoration initially   overperforms� due to overstocking of canopy tree species.
#Text=Over time, tree stocking rates generally decrease to within the completion criteria range, but species richness declines significantly.
#Text=Fire in restoration negatively impacts five of the six restoration attributes (Table�S1) and is a significant ecosystem resilience risk.
#Text=The average period between wildfires in the NJF prior to European settlement was 81 years (Burrows et al�1995).
#Text=This interval has decreased since settlement to less than 20 years and much of the forest now experiences prescribed burns more frequently than natural fire frequencies (McCaw�2013).
#Text=Restoration carries significantly higher levels of litter and fine, aboveground fuels than the reference ecosystem to at least 10 years of age (Morley et al�2004; Smith et al�2004).
#Text=Post_fire, restoration develops an aboveground fine fuel layer of�Acacia�and other fast_growing species that are significantly less common in the NJF, regardless of fire history (Grant�2003).
#Text=These species can maintain higher fuel loads than the reference ecosystem for decades (  eg Fig�7, Supplement�S1).
#Text=This altered fuel structure, combined with the lower canopy height in restored areas, makes severe crown fires significantly more likely (Cruz et al�2022; Zylstra et al�2023).

#Text=While there is an initial increase in plant species richness in restoration up to 5 years post_fire, after this, the loss of species post_fire is significantly faster than the reference ecosystem (Campbell et al�2023).

#Text=With fires in the jarrah forest becoming more frequent and more severe (and expected to continue to do so in the drying climate), the effects of fire on restoration, and subsequent impacts on the surrounding forest are likely to increase.

#Text=Newly established restoration, which has topsoil applied but limited vegetation established, typically has an increased risk of weed infestation due to the lack of competition with native vegetation.
#Text=It has been reported that from establishment, native vegetation gradually outcompetes the ephemeral exotic species invasion (  eg Daws et al�2021).
#Text=However, these studies do not consider the impact of fire, particularly repeated fires over time.
#Text=Studies that have included fire impacts consistently show increased weed loads over time (Supplement�S1).

#Text=Effect of Improved Restoration Practices Over the Study Period\rAlcoa s long_running research program has facilitated adaptive management of restoration practices, including topsoil_handling, increased initial species richness, reduced legumes in seed mixes, fertilizer rates, and specialized propagation and hand planting of recalcitrant species (Koch�2015).

#Text=Due to the variability and low similarity of restoration outcomes, Tacey and Glossop (1980) recommended topsoil stripping to 2 cm depth or stripping to 5 cm depth and respreading to 1�2 cm depth, noting that this would reduce the vegetation density of already under_performing restoration.

#Text=Unpublished reports from Alcoa in the mid_1980s indicated that stripping topsoil to 5 or 15 cm produces   comparable� germinable seed composition (Alcoa of Australia Ltd.�1987), which led to the adoption of 15 cm stripping depth as the operational target in the mid_1980s.

#Text=However, the limited replicates of this study (two sites per treatment) and the variability of soil seed bank studies and other double_stripping trials (Tacey & Glossop�1980; Koch et al�1996; Ward et al�1997), indicate that the   comparability� may be due to the high variability of the topsoil seed bank in the forest (Supplement�S1).
#Text=The persistently low density of many non_recalcitrant species in restoration areas, to the point of absence, may be attributable to the decision to increase the depth of stripping in the 1980s.
#Text=As noted previously, gains in initial vegetation species richness since 1988 have not translated to long_term increases in richness as restoration ages.
#Text=Therefore, these gains cannot be used as indicators of a sustainable improvement in restoration outcomes.
#Text=Longitudinal studies show much of the underlying legume dominance remains after several decades.
#Text=Changes in rates of applied legume seed density initially reported improved outcomes but became less significant over time (Daws et al�2019) to the point of insignificance (Daws et al�2023).
#Text=Similarly, altered rates of fertilizer application have mixed results and do not significantly alter the decline in species richness over time (Supplement�S1).

#Text=Regardless of fertilizer or seed treatment, legumes continue to comprise 30�40% of understory plants present in restoration for at least 30 years, compared with 10% of understory plants in the reference ecosystem (Supplement�S1) and become more dominant again after fire.

#Text=While recent publications have shown increasing species richness and similarity to the reference ecosystem with increasing age of restoration (  eg Daws et al�2021,�2022), these have not taken into account some or all of the factors listed below.
#Text=Some of these fundamentally influence results:\r1.

#Text=Inconsistent, small quadrat locations (Nichols & Michaelsen�1986), which can significantly alter results (up to 75% in Ward et al�1990, using the same longitudinal sites as Daws et al�2022).\r2.
#Text=Initial� surveys performed 4 years after restoration commenced, by which stage ephemerals and some shorter_lived post_disturbance species would have senesced.\r3.
#Text=Effect of time since fire (some longitudinal surveys performed 0.5�2 years post_fire).\r4.

#Text=Inaccurate identification of seedlings at 12�18 months of age (particularly slower_growing recalcitrants), which can cause increased measured richness over the first few years of restoration (  eg Norman et al�2006).\r5.
#Text=Exceptionally low species richness in early surveys of both standard and adapted restoration practices for some longitudinal studies (<10th percentile), possibly due to 4 above.\r6.

#Text=The statistical power of differences over time and between treatments with low replicates (often fewer than six data points, with largely overlapping ranges between fixed variables�Supplement�S1).\r7.
#Text=Substantial distances between reference model sites (up to 35 km apart) result in low baseline targets for similarity indices (see Section�4.3).\r8.
#Text=Presence/absence_based similarity indices, which do not reflect the functional composition of the restoration (particularly with large spatial scales�see [7]).
#Text=For example, regardless of age or treatment, legumes continue to be significantly over_represented in restoration (Supplement�S1), but this would not be reflected in Sorensen similarities�.

#Text=Due to the ecological importance of recalcitrant species in the reference ecosystem (Lambers et al�2022) and their low densities in restored areas from topsoil seedbank and broadcast seed germination, there has been substantial investment in their restoration, including labor_intensive division of rhizome material, cutting and seed propagation, and tissue culture (Alcoa of Australia Ltd.�1998).

#Text=Average survivability rates of recalcitrant species planted into restoration areas under various conditions are as high as 50% after 15 years (Daws & Koch�2015), though this varies significantly.

#Text=Despite production of up to half a million recalcitrant seedlings per year (Koch�2015), and planting up to 1000/ha per year, this leaves an estimated restoration gap of at least 350 million recalcitrant plants across the 280 km2�of cleared forest to date, excluding clonal species.
#Text=Discussion.

#Text=Effectiveness of the Standards\rGiven the complexities involved in the project (threatened biodiversity hotspot, complex biodiversity, large area of operations, and long timeframes), the effective application of the standards generic framework and criteria is a strong endorsement of their design as a tool for informing restoration outcome quality.

#Text=The only attribute metric that required adjustment was�Species composition�(species richness alone was not a reliable indicator and evenness did not reflect the low levels of similarity between restoration and the reference ecosystem).

#Text=Alcoa has been recognized internationally for their restoration outcomes, and has self_reported restoration scores of 90% (Grant�2006; Koch & Hobbs�2007), whereas this standards_based review gave a significantly lower rating of 2_stars against Alcoa s medium_term goal of 4_stars.
#Text=The discrepancy between previously reported quality and this review is attributable primarily to the age of restoration assessed, and to the metrics used.

#Text=Previous self_reported evaluations were based primarily on the initial species richness of the understory and stocking densities of the canopy tree species, with the restoration trajectory assumed to converge toward the reference ecosystem if these metrics rated high in early_stage restoration (Grant�2006).

#Text=Several decades have shown these indices do not reflect future restoration trajectory, with initial vegetation species richness unrelated to species richness as restoration ages, and the consistent decline in species richness over time resulting in substandard development of vegetation strata and faunal habitat features.
#Text=Therefore, the time required to establish a robust restoration trajectory is fundamental to ensuring restoration monitoring programs are effective and fit for purpose.
#Text=The need for a�  more holistic landscape_scale assessment of rehabilitation performance over time� was noted in the recent Alcoa_funded review (Jaspar et al�2023, p 39).

#Text=Attribute Interactions\rThe interactions between attributes and their resultant   �weighting� are an important consideration, with a significant impact on restoration planning, monitoring, and ultimately outcomes.

#Text=This is as per detailed quantitative research, such as (Robinson et al�2023), who demonstrated that substrate can be up to 100 times more critical to mine restoration outcomes than other factors that commonly receive more attention (  eg genetic provenance).

#Text=Topsoil properties strongly influence plant growth in the NJF (Zhou et al�2022), which is reflected in the variable results of fertilizer trials conducted by Alcoa over the past 30 years (  eg Norman et al�2006; Standish et al�2008; Daws et al�2019,�2022).

#Text=This variability may be due to site_ or quadrat_specific effects such as distance from the edge of the pit, variations in topsoil thickness, or ripping depth, all potentially overriding fertilizer effects.

#Text=Restoration topsoil depth averaging 40% less than the reference model and ripping of restoration areas after topsoil spreading mixing the topsoil, overburden, and pit_floor materials (resulting in further dilution and deep burial of the seed bank) may also contribute to the highly variable results.

#Text=As vegetation structure affects the functional return and composition of key faunal groups such as bats, reptiles, and pollinating insects (Burgar et al�2017; Tudor�2021), the flow_on effects of substrate on vegetation quality to fauna further reinforce attribute interactions.
#Text=The lack of species_specific floral resources in restoration may lead to network simplification (Vamosi et al�2006) or potentially collapse.

#Text=This presents a significant issue for Alcoa, as the bauxitic ore they mine defines the mid_slope to upland jarrah forest ecosystem substrate (Havel & Mattiske�2000; Bradshaw�2015) and failure to restore this vegetation complex to the landscape post_mining may effectively remove critical ecosystem elements from the wider spatial mosaic of the NJF.

#Text=The impact of mining and poor restoration trajectory on pollinator networks is one of potentially many mutualisms significantly impacted by forest fragmentation, leading to decay in ecosystem health over time (Siegel et al�2023).

#Text=Restoration Trajectory\rResearch published in conjunction with Alcoa shows the ecosystem functions of restoration areas at 25 years age (as measured by plant functional diversity indices) are compromised (Standish et al�2021), with the standards analysis used here showing most indices are not on a trajectory to return to the levels of the reference ecosystem.

#Text=Monitoring and adaptive intervention will be required over long timeframes (  eg >100 years for cockatoo and bat roosting and nesting capacity to develop in canopy trees; Burgar et al�2015; Doherty et al�2016), particularly in legacy restoration sites where it has taken several decades for crucial restoration gaps become apparent .

#Text=Critically, as outlined in Bradby and Cross (2023), the NJF is a highly complex ecosystem, with species diversity, deep_time phylogenetic lineages, and complex species_by_species specialization that have accumulated in climate_buffered landscapes with specific substrate characteristics (Hopper et al�2021).

#Text=While restoration of such ecosystems has been achieved by others to 3_ and 4_star ratings over one to two decades, including post_mining, none of these involve permanent removal of the defining substrate material, or are on scales orders of magnitude lower than Alcoa s operation (Young et al�2022).

#Text=Given that local_scale hydrology is a more significant factor of vegetation composition in the NJF than physical or chemical substrate properties on their own (Fordyce et al�2007), the reduced infiltration rates and increased occurrences of waterlogging in restoration (Croton & Bari�1997) may also contribute to the poor long_term trajectory of restoration areas.
#Text=This is of relevance, since Havel and Mattiske (2000) use landform, soil structure, and soil hydrology before vegetation species to define the vegetation complexes of the forest.
#Text=The lack of fresh, thick topsoil for 65 km2�of cleared forest where restoration has not yet commenced represents a significant liability to ongoing and future restoration.

#Text=As the process of clearing vegetation for mining, including removing tree root stumps, already significantly alters the topsoil seed bank and results in a markedly different understorey composition (Koch et al�1996), efforts to improve double_stripping practices are unlikely to result in significant improvements in restoration outcomes.

#Text=There are ecosystem structural factors in restoration areas that will require continued active management for a century or more, such as maintaining an appropriate level of CWD, attainment of old_growth ecosystem features (trees and understory), and understory species enrichment.

#Text=Nesting boxes are temporary measures, requiring maintenance or replacement each 3�4 years (Saunders et al�2022) and therefore will require ongoing maintenance or replacement at least 30 times before canopy trees reach hollow_bearing age.

#Text=The effective absence of mid_story plant species in restoration means that this structural layer is unlikely to return to restoration areas regardless of age and potentially permanently affect utilization of restoration areas by some fauna species (  eg Burgar et al�2017).

#Text=While research to improve the diversity and density of recalcitrant species in restoration is ongoing (Alcoa of Australia Ltd.�2019a), establishing these species in sufficient quantities is a significant technical and logistical constraint due to (1) the high densities of these species in the reference ecosystem, (2) recalcitrant seedlings/propagations failing to establish in restoration areas, and (3) the unproven ability of those that are present to survive and regenerate into self_sustaining populations after planting (Daws & Koch�2015; Norman & Koch�2007).
#Text=Conclusion.
#Text=The standards provided an effective framework to assess the multiple and interacting factors that drive restoration outcomes.

#Text=For this review, the generic framework and ratings were highly applicable to the project, despite the high biodiversity richness, ecological complexity, large spatial extent, and long timeframes involved.

#Text=The 2_star rating of restoration against Alcoa s 4_star medium_term goal and poor to declining trajectory means that restoration areas do not (1) return to a state similar to the native reference ecosystem, (2) improve over longer timeframes, nor (3) show sustained improved outcomes from adaptive management processes.

#Text=The   self_weighting� of restoration attributes through interactions between sub_attributes indicates that the removal of the substrate on which the vegetation communities have evolved may be a significant underlying cause of Alcoa s poor restoration outcomes, as substrate conditions affect every other attribute.
#Text=Crucially, fundamental ecosystem attributes have not been considered in some previous assessments, and previously assumed restoration trajectories have been shown to be false.

#Text=Adaptive management efforts may have been hindered by the timeframe required to establish and monitor restoration trajectories in this ecosystem, as some initially successful adaptive management trials have taken several decades to prove ineffective.

#Text=Similarly, commonly used ecosystem indices, such as initial plant species richness, have shown after decades to be unrelated to medium_ or long_term restoration trajectories, further hindering the success of adaptive management efforts.

#Text=Most factors that contribute to under_performing restoration are technically complex to rectify due to being inherent to the mining operation (  eg substrate condition) or the ecological nature of size of the under_performance (  eg absent recalcitrant species, weeds and legumes, and lack of habitat features).

#Text=These complexities are compounded by the large scale of operations (>280 km2�to date) and lack of proven ability to establish restoration on a trajectory toward the desired restoration goal, despite the investment and efforts of Alcoa over the last 60 years.

#Text=The NJF is the largest remaining contiguous and intact ecosystem in the southwest Australia biodiversity hotspot and therefore represents an internationally significant and unique conservation asset, with many threatened species.
#Text=Whether Alcoa can successfully transform this extractive megaproject into a   mega_eco project (Levinthal & Weller�2023) is uncertain but vital for the future of this fragile and at_risk biome.

#Text=Given the evidence to date, and consistent with the standards, the promise of ecological restoration should not be used to justify the continued destruction of this globally significant biodiverse ecosystem; rather, additional impacts to intact jarrah forests should be avoided (the leading principle of the Mitigation Hierarchy) until when and if successful long_term and resilient restoration outcomes are proven.

#Text=Acknowledgments\rThe mining activities reviewed in this document occur on the lands of the Binjareb people of the Noongar Nation of southwest Australia, and we acknowledge their continuing connection to country and culture and pay our respect to their elders, who cared for these forests for 60,000 years.

#Text=The authors wish to thank the staff of the State Library of Western Australia and the State Recordestern Australia and the State Records Office for their assistance in sourcing some of the older documents and reports cited in this study.
